I thought I'd write this little hypothetical scenario to help those who had never watched Lost understand what it felt like to be a die-hard Lost fan at the ending moments of the finale last night.  I know some fans don't agree with me, but I think this will more or less sum up the feelings of the vast majority of posters I've seen online since last night.  As always, this is just what it felt like to me.  If you felt differently, I'm glad for you.  I'd rather be you than me right now.

So indulge me in a hypothetical...

Imagine you love murder mysteries.  You start reading a book that is touted as the great murder mystery of the ages.  You get hooked easily in the first chapter.  In the first few pages, the author presents you with a man's corpse.  We don't know his identity, but we quickly learn that his life is shrouded in mystery.  By the end of the first chapter, the author has presented us with several important questions.  Who is this man?  Who killed him?  Why did they kill him?  How did they kill him?

You read the second chapter.  You're presented with many characters who are somehow connected with the man.  You get the idea that one of them (or maybe a group of them) hold all the answers.  Continuously through the chapter, the author keeps repeating the same questions.  Who is this man?  Who killed him?  Why did they kill him?  How did they kill him?

The third chapter introduces more characters.  Soon you begin to think that maybe you care more about the characters than the questions the author has posed.  But the author is having none of it.  He begins to pepper those questions into the body of the chapters now and not just at the end.  You are relentlessly forced to confront the same questions.  Who is this man?  Who killed him?  Why did they kill him?  How did they kill him?

In the subsequent chapters, you begin to wonder if the author had the end of the book planned when he started.  Events are muddled and characters act strangely.  You read an interview with the author in which he assures you that he's known the ending all along.  He promises that if you just trust him, you will know the answers to all the questions he has posed.  He's been a good writer so far, so you trust him.  You go back to pondering the questions.  Who is this man?  Who killed him?  Why did they kill him?  How did they kill him?

Finally you near the end of the book.  There are a few subplots that begin to be wrapped up and answered.  At the end of every paragraph you are promised by some character (or the narrator) that soon you will know the answers to all the questions.  Who is this man?  Who killed him?  Why did they kill him?  How did they kill him?

You have arrived at the end.  You hold your breath and turn to the final page.  You are about to have the answers you've been promised for so long.  You rest your eyes upon the final page and see...

A picture of a rabbit with a pancake on its head.

You blink in surprise.  This wasn't at all what you'd expected.  Underneath the picture, you find the last words of the book.  They read:  "It turns out the answers to those questions weren't that important after all.  Instead, enjoy the knowledge that this bunny lives in a happy home and gets plenty of carrots every day."

Now imagine it took you SIX YEARS to read that book.

And just for argument's sake, imagine that when you first started reading the book a bunch of people had posted online saying, "I bet they never answer anything and at the end we just get a picture of a bunny."  The author didn't take that well and responded in many interviews saying, "I can assure you that we'll answer everything and there will definitely not be a picture of a bunny at the end."  After you read the final chapter you send the author an email saying, "But I thought you said they were wrong about the bunny picture."  The author replies, "Well, technically that's true.  They didn't say it would be a picture of a bunny with a pancake on its head."

You sit and stare at the closed book and wonder how to feel about all this.  You might have liked the bunny ending if only the author hadn't persisted with those damned questions.  You liked most of the book.  It was a fun read and full of good characters.  But when you view the story as a whole, you can't help but feel cheated and lied to by the author.

There you have it, guys.  Now you know what it's like to be a Lost fan today.

Last night, I had an incredible dream.  In it, I felt safe... comforted... at peace... special... and most importantly, loved. 

(And for Pete's sake, get your minds out of the gutter.  It wasn't one of those.  Can we move on now?  Thanks.)

As they are wont to do, my alarm woke me at the best part of the dream.  So, I hit snooze and rolled over.  I was desperate to find my way back to that place where I had all those things I feel I lack in my waking world.  It worked.  I fell asleep again and quickly resumed the dream at almost exactly the spot where I had left it.

I replayed that little scene over the course of several hours.  Alarm.  Snooze.  Dreaming.  All to escape the bright, cold, lonely reality of my bedroom.  I just had to return to that safe, warm, loving place for a little longer.  Eventually, I turned off the alarm.  I hated it for coming between me and the world I wanted.  I returned to the dreaming intent on staying for as long as I could.

However, this time, the dreaming was different.  The people in it slowly turned from caring to caustic.  What was once love had turned to scorn.  I was confused and terrified in this new dream.  Why had they turned on me?  Why did these same people, who had loved me just moments before, now hate and mock me?


I awoke in my bedroom.  I was still cold and alone, but now I was depressed as well.  What had gone wrong?  What had happened to destroy the fantasy?

Lying there in the harsh light of reality, I had a thought.  We all have dreams we chase.  But some dreams, like those we have every night, are nice, but ultimately unattainable, fantasies.  They are great places to visit, and they can even give us respite in troubled times.  But while the people and places in my dream were from my reality, that would never be the reality of them.  Not understanding that, I chased the dream.  I tried to force it to become my reality.  The dream responded to my hubris by showing me my actual reality.

We have to know which dreams we can chase and which should be left to those fantasies that soothe us during slumber.  Otherwise, the harsh light of day will always find us back in our bedrooms... depressed and alone.

Forgive me, Morpheus.

(Cross-posted to Facebook.  You can comment here or there.)

So earlier on Facebook, I posted the following: "Conan O'Brien just made me cry.  I didn't even cry at Johnny's last show."

Which prompted Chris Mezzolesta to reply: "You might possibly have been a little young to understand the impact that Carson had on entertainment as a whole."

Now, no offense at all to Chris (who is a good friend and I know meant no disrespect), but I always get mildly annoyed when people discount what I say due to my age.  So I felt that I had to let you all in on exactly what this whole situation means to me, personally.

I've always had problems being a "day person." I've never had what most would consider a "normal" sleep cycle.  My parents had a saying when I was young: "You can put her to bed, but you can't put her to sleep."  Eventually, they learned that without something to distract me, I would stay up singing or playing with toys and would keep them up as well.  So they caved in and gave me a small black-and-white TV in my room. 

This meant, unlike many people my age, that Johnny Carson was a massive part of my childhood.  I watched him most nights thanks to that little TV.  Sometimes I'd watch with my father if there was an interesting guest or something he wanted to use as a learning tool (my father has always been an educator 24/7).  So when Carson retired, I knew pretty well what was going on and the implications of the whole thing.  I was sad to see Carson go, and the emotions that went with watching that last show are still fresh in my mind all these years later.  Thinking of Bette's rendition of "One For My Baby" sitting on that desk still gets me all warm and fuzzy and nostalgic in all the right ways.

But Conan has been a much bigger part of my life for much longer.  And I feel connected to him in a way that I never did with Carson.  I will grant that some of that is due to my age, yes.  But Conan always felt like one of my best friends.  He was geeky, witty, and smart.  He spoke to me in a way Carson never could.  He'd come from SNL (another HUGE part of my childhood) during some of its final good years, and had written for Simpsons during some of their best.  His humor was mine.

I never liked Leno nearly as much, despite his frequent guest-host appearances.  I watched a bit when he took over.  I liked some of the bits (like Headlines).  But he never really spoke to me.  I had given up on the Tonight Show under Leno's reign even as a kid.  I would switch to Nick At Nite instead.  But a few months in, I caught one of Conan's early shows.  I'll grant he was pretty rough in the beginning.  But even at that age, I knew I liked him.  He quickly became appointment watching for me.  So while the Tonight Show faded from my life, Late Night rolled in to fill that spot.  Conan was my favorite late night host.  Letterman had some funny stuff.  Leno did, too.  But Conan was MY host.

So for 17 years, I watched Late Night with Conan O'Brien.  I loved all the bits.  He always felt like more of Carson's successor to me than Leno (although Carson himself was said to have believed that title belonged to Letterman).  So when they announced years ago that Conan would eventually get the Tonight Show, I was ecstatic.  It felt like I'd been waiting since I was a kid for this to happen.  And in a very real sense, I had been.  I was thrilled to have the show that was such a huge part of my childhood feel like it was mine again.  And for 7 months, I felt that same thrill watching it.

And now that is gone.  See, I'm not mad at NBC for bad programming or horrible judgment (although all that is true and does annoy me greatly).  I'm mad that they took away that part of my childhood... again.  And after tonight, the Tonight Show goes back to being that disappointment that made me lose interest even at such a young age.  They hurt MY host.  They killed his dream... and mine, too.  They let vindictiveness and greed win out over hard work and kindness.  And they've left that part of me that still longs for the good old days wonder if the Tonight Show will ever feel like my home again.

John Hodgman sent out a message tonight on Twitter that read: "Saying farewell to an entertainer. Jocks win. This time."  That's what it feels like to all of us who watched Conan and felt he spoke for us.  NBC has put us back on the playground to suffer those same petty injustices that made childhood hell.

But Conan's final words tonight were of grace.  He got to live that dream for a few months, and I got to live it with him.  And once again, I am 10 years old watching a cynical, spiteful, intelligence-insulting, big-chinned loudmouth steal a part of my childhood from me.

And that's what really made me cry tonight.

For those of us in my generation, she was best known as Olivia on Sesame Street.  I also post this video because it has Linda Bove in it.  Linda's appearance on Sesame Street was my first exposure to Sign Language.  Because of her (and to a lesser extent, Marlee Matlin) I learned to sign at an early age and later studied it in college.  In any case, enjoy my favorite song from Olivia and Linda.

My mother used to sing this song frequently both at home and performing in churches.  I don't think I've heard it since she died.  It came to mind today.  Maybe someone out there needs it as much as I did today.  Either way, it's still a beautiful song.

I'm desperately wanting to listen to the song "Evil Laugh" by Seanan McGuire.  But I can't find a copy or video or anything.  

Sad ferret is sad.
What traits would or do make you prefer the villain over the hero?

I usually refer to November as my "month of suck" or "month of pain" or some other such term.

November is always the month most associated with my mother's memory.  November 1 was her birthday.  She was married in November.  November 10 was the day she died.  She was buried in November.  Thanksgiving, a once enjoyable holiday filled with family and food has, for 18 years now, become filled with painful memories and grief.  Not a day goes by without me missing her, but for this one month, the grief is heightened.

Today, we would have celebrated her 52nd birthday.

My father and I have associated the following song with her memory for years.


Happy birthday, mama.  I miss you.

So, as most of you know, I moved to Illinois four months ago with a simple dream:  to find a job and not have to return to Georgia.

After a rocky start due to all the wonders of un-medicated bipolar, I finally got the ball rolling.  I signed up for help from DuPage County (which is the most affluent in all of IL as it turns out).  Through their wealth of programs, I was able to get a steady psychiatrist, regular medication, a job coach to help me look for work, and quite a few other things as well.

When Sara bought a house (yay!) and decided to have her wonderful fiance Luke move in (also yay!), that sort of left me with no place to go.  However, things once again took an upward swing as I was able to find a job.  It's only a part time, minimum wage cashier job and it's only guaranteed to be seasonal, but it is far better than the nothing I had before.  With a job, I started to hunt for a place to live.

I needed a few things in a new place.  I needed it to have a roommate I could tolerate (naturally).  I needed it to be between $400-500/mo after including utilities (which must include internet as well).  I needed it to be near public transportation.  Finally, I needed it to be in DuPage County so I could keep all the services I was getting.

Things did not go well at first.  None of the posters on Craigslist with places that met my needs ever contacted me back.  Finally, a girl named Amber gave me a call.  I met with her and found that her place had everything I wanted (including laundry on site!).  She's a geek herself and has two cats.  We hit it off immediately.  She wanted me as her roomie, but I had to undergo a background/credit check before her landlord would let me move in.

Today, after much stress and uncertainty, I got the news that I was approved to be her new roommate!  I get to stay in IL!  I get to start my new job this coming week!  I get to keep my doctor, my meds, and all my services from DuPage!

Best of all... I DO NOT HAVE TO GO BACK TO GEORGIA!!!!!!!!!ONE!!!11!

Over half of my stuff (well, the stuff in IL at least) has already been moved into the new place.  Amber is coming in the morning to help me move the rest of my clothes and small things.  Luke will help me move my futon, dresser, and computer on Monday.  By Monday night, I'll be in the new apartment.  The first week will be a bit hectic.  Amber's old roomie (who is breaking her half of the lease and leaving Amber in a bind) can't have her stuff out until the 3rd.  So, I can't have my bedroom until then.  Also, there is another girl staying in Amber's room right now.  She was going to be the new roommate, but she couldn't live with cats.  She is getting out by the 1st.  So, for a few days, I will be sleeping on the couch, and there may be four of us in a two bedroom apartment.  However, since this is an inconvenience from hell (and since the landlord is forcing the old roomie to pay October's rent), Amber has offered to just let me split half of her rent for the month.  Since I'm only paying half of what I planned to this month, I'll be able to furnish my room a bit more and get some things I need for the winter (like a decent coat).  So, I'm willing to go through an odd week.

There's much more to this story.  I've been through many ups and downs and lots of stress.  However, I don't really want to dwell on that at the moment.  For this short span, everything is working out for me even if it hasn't worked out exactly like I'd imagined.  I am determined to focus on the good.  I shall keep looking for a steady job in my field that pays me more than the minimum.  I have a few leads and am always looking for more.  (If you know of any jobs for someone with a writing/linguistics/tutoring/theatre background in the area, let me know.)

The universe has been kind to me.  As such, I will refrain from setting it on fire... for now.

(P.S.  If you're in the Chicagoland area and we haven't gotten to hang out yet, send me a private message with how to contact you.  I want to hang out with more friends.)

Here's a hypothetical for all of you:

You have been hired to write a blurb about me similar to those "About the Author" paragraphs that are printed on book jackets.  How would you describe me to someone who has never met me or heard about me?  Your response can be as serious or humorous as you'd like, but I ask that it be what you would HONESTLY submit if you were given such an assignment.  Please keep responses in third person.  That means I should only ever be referred to with words such as Kiki, she, or her.  I ask for at least 3 sentences, but you may go on for as long as you like.

So, what details would you think important to tell the world about me?

(Anonymous comments are open for those without LJ accounts.  As always, I ask that you sign your comment with a nickname that I will recognize.  Thanks.)

I know that, like me, many of you consider Jim Henson to be a huge influence on your lives.  But what exactly has he taught you?

Please respond to this with as many lessons as you'd like to share that you've learned from Jim Henson's work or life.  They can be positive or negative, happy or sad.  I'm looking for anything Jim Henson did that had an influence on the way you view the world.  Feel free to include anecdotes, quotes, video, or links if you see fit.

Anonymous comments are open for anyone who doesn't have an LJ account.  If anyone would like to post a link to this topic in their LJ, please feel free.  I would like to get as much discussion on this as possible.

Thanks for all your help.

I couldn't help but notice that the American Idol live tour is playing two dates fairly near Chicago.

The coolest bit is that one of them is actually going to be ON MY BIRTHDAY, Aug. 28th!  And it'll be in Milwaukee, the hometown of my second-favorite Idol of the season, Danny Gokey.

The other will be in Rosemont, IL on Sept. 2nd.

Details are here.

I really want to go to the Milwaukee one.  That would be like coolest birthday present ever.

Would any of my IL or WI friends be up for a concert?  I've always wanted to see how the live shows are handled.  Curious ferret is curious.

If you have sent me anything via my voiceofkiki (dot) com email addy in the last few weeks, please resend it.  It seems my email has been terribly borked for awhile now.  It's finally working again, so it should be safe to resend.

This is especially important if you or anyone you know has sent me anything about job stuff.  I haven't gotten any of it.

Eep!

Thanks.

I especially love how it makes it look like part of the song is a fight between Jezza and my Hamster.  I also love how there were no pics of the Stig.  Because current Stig may be white, but he's nothing if not cool.

On a related note, does anyone know where I can get some cool Top Gear icons?  Or maybe just some general Brit Fandom ones?  I want something appropriate for non-Whovian posts.

Yeah, fine.  I watch American Idol.  I watch it because I like Simon Cowell.  Yes, I know what you all think of him.  I know it's on Fox.  I know, I know.  I still don't care.  Let's move beyond the harassment and get to business shall we?

I would like to take you back to 2003.  Two hopeful young male singers stand on a stage waiting for Ryan "The More I See of Ant & Dec, The More I Hate Him" Seacrest to announce which one of them would be the next winner of American Idol.  Clay Aiken was the obvious choice.  He was the better performer and the more outstanding vocalist.  He had never been in the Bottom Three, the weekly group that get the lowest numbers of votes.  He had a huge fanbase.  However, when Seacrest made the announcement, we were told that his competition, Ruben Studdard, was the ultimate winner.  Studdard won the competition by 130,000 votes. 

Many fans were shocked.  How had Ruben beat out such obviously superior competition in the end?  Many theories were put forward at the time.  The most lingering of these is the idea that there was an error with the phone lines that caused possibly millions of Clay's votes not to be recorded.  However, the more likely scenario is that Clay lost because...

He had teh icky gay!  *insert scary fanfare here*  *also insert lightning and thunder*  *and let's toss in some poor female screaming*  *and how about some demonic laughter at the end, too*

Questions about Clay's sexuality were prevalent from the moment America first saw him.  And, let's be honest here, it was obvious all along.  However, all through the second season of American Idol, Clay maintained that he loved him some girls.  Even after he left the show and went on to decimate Studdard in albums sales, Aiken continued to deny his sexuality.  In fact, it was only last year that Clay finally decided to be truthful with the public and officially came out.

But it seems he came out long before that.  Former second season contestants have since claimed that Aiken told them was gay during the filming of the show.  It seems the producers knew as well.  So why was he so obscure with the public for so long?  It seems former Idol contestants may provide the answer to that as well.  A few former Idol hopefuls have said that Fox encouraged them to deflect questions about their sexuality during their time on the show.  Undoubtedly, this occured with Clay Aiken as well.

So why all this backstory tonight, dear friends?  Well, if any of you have been keeping up with this season of Idol, you'll know that we're in a similar situation again.  Tonight's grand finale will give us a new American Idol.  This time the competition has come down to Adam Lambert vs. Kris Allen.

Kris Allen is a cute, shy, sweet southern boy from Arkansas.  He plays guitar and piano.  His lovely wife sits in the audience during every show to cheer him on.  He has a very subdued performance style.  He's a nice singer, someone I'd love to have with me at karaoke.

Adam Lambert is an amazing singer and a brilliant performer.  He knows how to use the tools he is given.  He is from California.  He has a background in theatre and has appeared in musicals professionally before.  He also made a living as a performer at caberet shows.  He knows how to dress.  His hair is black and blue, and he rocks emo bangs with a punk twist.  His nails are painted, and he wears more makeup than Idol judge Paula Abdul.

To put it mildly, Adam Lambert just may be the gayest gay that ever gayed a gay.  And I love him for it.

Unfortunately, like all gay Idol contestants, he has been forced to deflect those nagging questions about his sexuality.  But, unlike Clay Aiken, he has never denied that he is gay.  He just takes the Anderson Cooper route.  When pictures of him kissing another man surfaced, Adam confirmed that they were of him and said that he had nothing to hide about his life.

When my Simon (boo and I'll hurt you) was asked by TV Guide about Adam Lambert's constant deflections of the gay question, he said:
"I think people only get bothered really when they know somebody’s hiding something. [Laughs] We’ve had that in the past! (Note: Read Clay Aiken here.)  We’ve obviously never had an issue with it (Note: I assume this means the judges and Simon's co-creator Simon Fuller and does not extend to Rupert Murdoch and Fox.), and nor should anybody else. It’s a huge step forward for the show. It’s just, do you like him as a person, as a singer, full stop."
 
But have we, as my Simon suggests, moved forward?  Many Right Wing nut-job groups have already formed online to encourage their followers to vote for anyone but Adam Lambert.  They don't think he casts the right image for an "American" Idol.  Simon Cowell himself has even gone on record saying that if Adam made the finals, he didn't think he would win.  Simon figured that either Kris Allen or third place contestant Danny Gokey would triumph because they were the "safe" choice, although he admits that Adam Lambert is the better singer.

So has America moved past our problems with teh icky gay?  Or is it, as my Simon seems to suggest, that we only had a problem with Clay Aiken because he was lying to us?  If this is true, why doesn't Simon think Adam is the "safe" choice?

After last night's final performance, I spent an hour and ten minutes on the phone dialing the three numbers provided for Adam Lambert.  In that time, I got through 40 times.  Well, there's my word on the subject.  40 votes for the better singer.

Adam Lambert doesn't need to win American Idol.  His career is assured.  I know that Simon Cowell has already figured out the rest of this boy's life.  If Adam's smart, he won't fight it.  He'll be a millionaire by the end of the year.  He'll be able to tour, star on Broadway, or whatever he desires.  But, if he wins, it may just show that Americans are on their way to forgetting about teh icky gay and seeing people like Adam as a person, as a singer, full stop.

Go Adam!

(Final note:  Comments may contain spoilers for the final results starting around 10 pm Eastern.  If you don't want to see them, stop looking around this time.)

My friend Amber is in the unfortunate position of having to find a home for a bonded pair of adult ferrets.  I would take them, but there is no room here for them.  Also, not having income isn't helping things.  So, if you or a friend would be able to give these sweet guys a home, please contact me ASAP!

The ferrets are:

Novella (M): 18 months old.  Beige color.  Very docile.  Great with kids.
Tavi (M): 1 year old.  Silver-Beige color.  Playful.  Still nips a bit hard at times, but never out of anger.

They will both need their shots renewed.  Neither has ever been vaccinated for distemper.

They come with cage, hammock, and pet carrier.

Please help us keep from sending these guys to a shelter.  If anyone you know is interested, contact me ASAP!

Love and huggles,
Kiki (and Novella and Tavi)

Well, I took Sara to the airport earlier.  She's going to join Luke and Shoebox at a con in Soviet Canuckistan somewhere.  Yay for them.  Hope you guys have fun.

Unfortunately, this leaves me with bugger all to do until Monday night when Sara returns.

Anyone in Chicagoland want to do anything this weekend?

Well, I have safely made it to my final destination at the lovely apartment of the supremely kind  .    My second flight last night was delayed for two hours in NC because they had to change the tires on the plane.  So   and I didn't make it here until after midnight.  We all chatted for a bit, watched Colbert, and then went to bed.  Well, they went to bed.  I stayed up and wrote for about an hour until my eyes began to glaze over.  I really didn't want to stop writing.  It feels so good to be writing again!  I need to get back to it in a few.  Maybe I'll make some chainmail stuffs as well.

I suddenly feel like being productive.  I'm not used to this feeling.  I hope it sticks.

Today's the day it gets better
This much I know
I'm gone, I'm gettin' out
And all you suckers can watch me go...


I'll have to leave for my flight around 3:30 PM or so.  Then   will pick me up from the airport and drive me to  's place.  When I get there, I'll probably post a sentence or two so you guys don't worry.

See you on the flip side in Chicago!

My flight leaves tomorrow afternoon at 5:55 PM.  I'll have to leave town a bit before 4 PM to make it to the airport on time.  This gives me about 32 hours to do everything that must be done.

I need to finish packing my life into boxes and moving those boxes into the loft.  That way my stuff can remain at my father's house hopefully undisturbed until I can move it into my own place.

I need to attempt to pack as many essentials into the 3 suitcases I can take with me on the flight as is humanly (or ferret-ly) possible.  I also need to keep each suitcase under 50 lbs.

I need to gather the few things (e.g. my guitar) that cannot come with me on the flight and take them to the UPS Store to be packaged and shipped.  I must also keep the things to be shipped to a minimum.

I need to go by the bank to deposit some money, close out one account, and find out their policy on closing an account from another state.  I've never had to do any of that before.  (EDIT:  Done!)

I need to go by the post office to get change of address forms.  I must then fill these forms out.

There are several other things that are on my list, but those are the really major ones.  I also need to find time to eat and sleep and stuff.

Kitsune and Happy are coming over at 9 AM to help me.  I hope we can get it all done.  I'm seriously freaking out, but I usually work best under heart-stopping pressure and impossible deadlines.  I'm hoping that skill works for me now.

Wish me luck, and don't expect me to be active online until late tomorrow night or sometime Thursday.

I was packing today while my dad was watching TV.  He looked up from the TV and stared at my face for a second.  This was the exchange that followed:

Dad: Your skin looks really good.  Clear.  Nice glow to it.
Me:  Perhaps packing does wonders for skin tone?
Dad:  I don't think so.  Maybe it's hope.


I actually had to have a moment to myself after that.


My flight leaves on Wednesday afternoon.  I have much to do before then.  I'm off to bed now.  Goodnight.

First things first... Attention
ladygwenlong
!!! You need to read this!


That being done, the rest of you read this, too. It contains important news.

As many of you know, I have recently made a decision to leave the rather dead-end town I've been stuck in for the last 20 years or so. At the start of April, I took a really crappy job under a horrifically ass-tastic manager for the sole purpose of saving money to move at the end of summer. Well, the job turned out to be an April Fool's joke as I was fired on my third day of employment for offering to work MORE hours. It seems this was somehow "disrespectful" to my manager since he makes the schedule, and therefore meant that I was questioning his authority. I was confused.

Anyway, after Operation Save Money and Move at Summer's End blew up in my face in a spectacular fashion unfortunately totally unlike the nifty Mythbusters 'splosions, I came to a decision.

It's time to GTFO.

I have been offered a place to stay with the lovely dement1a at her place in Chicago! I'll stay with her while I locate a job and save up the money for my own place. The ever puntherific has agreed to be my roomie once we save enough to move into an apartment.

The date for the move is now targeted for the week of May 5th or as soon after as I can arrange a flight. I know it's soon, but I need out ASAP. There's no future for me here.

Those of you in Georgia get ready to say farewell. Those of you in Chicago... Ferret's a'comin your way!

Love and huggles!

(P.S. I don't usually do this, but if any of you would like to donate to my moving fund, please do so through paypal to the address kiki@voiceofkiki.com with whatever you feel like giving. I've discovered some quite important things I lack for a trip/move like this. I don't even own a suitcase. I hate to ask, but there it is.)

I attempted to go to bed around midnight last night.  I am still sick, and the illness was treating me roughly yesterday.  So, I curled up in my bed with my copy of Nation by Terry Pratchett.  I bought the book when it first came out and, what with graduation and all, had not gotten around to reading it until now.

Around midnight, I started the first chapter in an attempt to calm my mind and beckon sleep.

I just finished the final page.

I have not slept.  I cannot remember the last time I accidentally inhaled a novel like that.  It was glorious.

Perhaps I'll go to sleep now.  Whoops.

(Side note:  I recently finished the book Playing for Keeps by my lovely friend Mur Lafferty.  I highly recommend it.  It was great fun.  I demand a sequel so that I may delight in it as well.)

Watchmen was totally awesome.

Things were changed, yes.  However, the movie satisfied even me.

A++.  Will watch again.


(Side note:  The same friend who made my Kiki pendant also made a recreation of Silk Spectre II's earings from the comic in anticipation of tonight's premiere.  He was kind enough to let me model them during the show.  I shall try to provide you all with pictures later.  They rock!)

Since I graduated, I've been looking for any sort of work around town that would let me pay my bills (and hopefully set a bit aside) while I look for more permanent employment.  Unfortunately, even in the best of times, jobs are hard to come by around here.  With the economy being what it is, the few jobs that were around seemed to be drying up.  I have been offered lodging with friends in other cities should I desire to look for work elsewhere, but I don't have enough money to pay for travel to any of those places (not to mention the money it takes to get an apartment and such once you find work).

Point being, I need money to facilitate my exodus from this crap town.

Well, I think I found myself a part-time job today.  A friend of mine knows the manager at our movie theater.  So, while we were there to get our tickets for tonight's Watchmen screening, he asked the manager if he might have a position free.  Turns out he did.  So I met with the manager, Scottie, and it seems like I will get the job if all the paperwork clears corporate.  Yay, me!

Cross your fingers, toes, paws, claws, fins, or whatever and hope everything works out.  It's not a long-term career, but it could at least keep me afloat while I job hunt.

And for those of you attending Marscon this weekend:  Travel safely, have fun, and rock the con!

I've been horrifically sick for days.  I caught some icky combo of tummy bug and sinus infection from my father.  Yay.  I pretty much lost all weekend.  I was doing better on Monday I thought, but yesterday, I got worse again.

Around 7 pm last night, I heard two loud booms which shook my house.  I walked outside to see if I could see something, but given the thick tree cover around my place, I couldn't see anything.  When my dad got home a few minutes later, I asked if he'd seen an accident or emergency vehicles in the area.  He said he hadn't seen anything.

As the night progressed, my condition deteriorated and I ended up lying on the couch groaning in pain.  But every now and then I still heard noises that sounded like banging or popping or sirens.  I kept asking my dad if he heard them and he always said I was just hearing the cat in the other room or something on tv.  I began to wonder if I was hallucinating.

This morning, I was awakened by a call from my dad.  While talking to the emergency services people that teach at his technical college, they mentioned all the excitement that had happened last night.  It seems that a mobile meth lab exploded last night in the subdivision adjacent to ours!  The force of the explosion shook the area and knocked over the gates of the subdivision.

The vidication I feel at having actually heard what I thought I heard is kinda burried under the realization that the next subdivision is filled with meth labs.

I still feel horrible.  Sitting upright makes me feel dizzy.  I no can brain cuz I haz teh sick.  I may go back to bed soon.  Don't expect me around much.  If I follow dad's example, I won't be well until this weekend sometime.  Joy.

My official college diploma just arrived in the mail.  I really have graduated.

Score point, ferret.

As many of you already know, my uncle (father's brother) is very sick.  We're not sure what is wrong with him and he keeps getting worse.

My father, his sister, and I are headed to South Carolina in a few minutes to visit him in the hospital.  We'll be gone for at least the majority of today.  We may stay longer if he takes a turn for the worse.

Please pray for him.

Please keep me up-to-date on any news you may have (personal, national, or international) via the comments, on Twitter (voiceofkiki), or on AIM/YIM.

You can say what you like about his politics.  You can discuss his plans.  You can even talk about about the history he's making as our nation's first African-American president.  However, there is a frequently overlooked landmark taking place today that shall be my focus.

Barack Obama will be America's first geek president.

This, I feel, deserves special mention.  We'll have a geek in office.  A geek leading the free world.  This, my friends, is truly momentous.

That our ever-so-soon-to-be president is an unabashed geek cannot be denied.  The man has a comic collection that rivals or exceeds most of ours.  He has read all the Harry Potter books.  He loves his Mac laptop (I'm letting this one slide).  When joking about how people saw him as a savior, Obama chose not a Biblical reference but instead insisted that his father's name was Jor-El.  This is a man who refused to give up his BlackBerry because he didn't want to live in a bubble of politics and respected his friends to tell him if he was acting like a fool.  When he wrote an open letter to his daughters in Parade magazine, Obama couldn't help but toss in a Spiderman reference.  When Joe Biden was finally chosen as running mate, Barack Obama revealed the news not in a press conference or interview.  He did it via Twitter.  (I wonder if the location on his Twitter account will be updated from Chicago to DC later today.)  His campaign relied heavily on grassroots efforts coordinated online.  The man is "one of us."

However, I don't think it's the pop culture references and the tech savvy that really prove this.  I think it is his attitude.  For all the complaints people hurl in our direction for being emo or callous, I think geeks are inherently optimistic.  Why else do we constantly work for change?  Why else do we throw ourselves into scientific pursuits?  Why else would we work to create new technologies and look beyond the stars?

Humanity is a constant disappointment to us, yes.  But why is that?  It is because we know that humanity can be better.  We should be better.  We can and should be inclusive.  We can and should be willing to see past racial, religious, gender, sexual, and physical differences.  We know that we can and should be a glorious light in the universe and an inspiration and example to any and all other life that may share this existence with us.

So we look to Orwell and Huxley and heed their warnings.  We follow Roddenberry, Asimov, and Straczynski who teach us acceptance and tolerance.  And we take the words of Lee, Eisner, and Moore who have given us our charge to be vigilant and responsible for our fellow beings.  We take it all and we form a community dedicated to the belief that humanity is meant for more.  Humanity can and must be better.

We have seen the Orwellian darkness threaten to consume us.  And we, as a people, stood up to the darkness and said "No more!"  This gives me hope.

Allow me to paraphrase Lennier speaking of Delenn in Babylon 5 (s4 ep13): Obama does not walk in the same world you and I walk in. He does not see the same world you and I see. In his world we are better than we are, we care more than we care. We act towards each other with compassion. I much prefer his world to that of my own, and I will not allow anything to threaten that.

Stephen Colbert, shortly after the election, asked how science fiction would show people that we're in the future if America really does have a black president.  Well, my friends... 

Welcome to the future.  May it be all we know it can and should be.

Love, huggles, and hope,
Kiki


What thoughts do you have on this historic day?  Also, who are your favorite movie presidents?  Mine has to be Bill Pullman as President Thomas Whitmore in Independence Day.  That final speech can rouse the patriot in me in a way few things can.

Well, the first con of the year that is on my radar is GAFilk.  I really wish I could go.  It was great fun last year despite the fact that I slept through most of it due to the previous week spent with my father in the hospital.  I have tons of friends that will be there.

I hope all you guys have fun.  Know I'll be missing you desperately.

I have to go deal with family today.  And there will be much rejoicing.  (Insert Monty Python-esque "yay" here.)

In preparation for doing laundry for todays dubious festivities, I looked up today's predicted weather.

Projected high temperature for my town today?

80 degrees!

That's not a typo.

No wonder I'm not feeling the Christmas spirit.  My town doesn't even know it's winter yet.

*head desk*

I mean, I'm no fan of biting cold or being snowed in, but I feel somehow cheated if I can wear shorts on Christmas without having a tropical getaway to go along with it.

Can I move yet?  The south sucks.  :(

While surfing TV Tropes tonight, I ran across a page titled "I Call It Vera."  The page is about the trope of characters naming inanimate objects, usually weapons, and is named after Jayne Cobb's declaration on the tv show Firefly that his favorite gun was named Vera.

Most of the examples listed under the article are names of various objects fictional characters own.  Unlike many of the tropes, there is a section in the article for musical references.  Most of these are examples of famous musicians naming their guitars.  No big surprise. 

However, this was the top example:

Devo Spice apparently named his Atari "Heather".

The included hyperlink to the FuMP is kept intact from the original source.


Sometimes my life is odd.  Then there are times like today when my brain just wants to collapse into a tiny black hole or something.

Wow.

I seem to have run out of education.  Now what?

Well, I beat the final boss of academia today.  Tonight, I had a graduation party.  A now-former professor brought me a bottle of champagne.  My friend Bert brought me a bottle of Tullamore Dew (yeah, baby). 

But the real gem of the evening was the handmade necklace my dear friend Carter made for me.



Now that is love.

Our quickly-produced Mickey and Judy play will be performed tonight.  I can't wait.  We have costumes, sets, props.  I am listed in the program as an Actor, Lighting Designer, and Dramaturg.  Oh yeah.  I'm so proud of us.  

I hope people actually show up...

For those of you in/near Georgia, I point out that there is a Nerdcore concert in Marietta tonight at Swayze's.  Directions are here.  MC Frontalot, YTCracker, and MC Lars are coming through on their one Georgia tour stop.  The venue is a no-booze/no-smoking all ages place (although the show might have some questionable material... nothing too bad).  Show starts at 7 pm.  Tickets are $10.

I'm thrilled to be going.  Not only are these guys amazing performers, but they're also good friends.  This tour has been a bit hellish for them, sadly.  Major car crash that wrecked most of their equipment, scared their keyboardist into quitting, and nearly claimed their lives seems to have been the worst of it.  However, they've been having a lot of other problems.  I intend to spend tonight dispensing huggles (and a bit of hoarded monies) in an attempt to ease their pain.

If you can make it to the show, I know you'll have a ton of fun.  These guys know how to put on a show.

I'm in the midst of a quite hellish week.  I'm trying to get everything done so that I can pass my classes so that I can graduate so that I won't have to do this crap anymore.  I have 2 papers, 2 portfolios, 3 revisions, 1 quiz, and various other homework due before Friday.  I also have to find time to work on a majorly difficult painting.  

Oh, and I have rehearsals.  Can't forget about those.

I will mention a few things here.  When I'm stressed, I can't eat.  Plus, I am hypoglycemic.  My blood sugar drops when I don't eat and when I'm forced to do strenuous activity.  Also, my part in the play is VERY physical.

We ran the entire play THREE times tonight.  Back-to-back.  The only "break" was to get notes and reset.

I made my final exit (which signals the play's end) and heard the director call "scene."  The next thing I remember is Kenneth in my face looking quite worried and shaking me.  I was on the floor.  Yup.  I passed out.  When they figured out what was wrong with me, they got me a quick snack to bring my blood sugar up a bit.  Then Kenneth walked me across the parking lot to the Wendy's and sat with me while I got something more substantial.

I'm fine now.  I'm exhausted and stressed, though.  I may take a nap.  I have to revise 3 pieces and prepare my portfolio for Creative Writing tomorrow.  I also have to study for a quiz in the morning.  A nap may be a good idea.

Two good things came from the crap that was tonight, though.  Firstly, I made it through rehearsal and only passed out once the director called scene.  I think that says something about my professionalism.  Secondly, I got to have a nice chat with Kenneth while I ate.  That cheered me greatly.  I'm so lucky to have a friend like him.  I can't thank him enough.  Seriously.

Still Alive:  The new Banned from Argo?

Discuss.


(Feel free to link or point other interested parties to this thread for discussion.  However, I don't want to x-post to any community.  Thanks for respecting that.)

So, we're doing that Irish play night on December 10th.  I play the Fool in "On Baile's Strand" by Yeats.  It's a great play.  It's a great part.

Before now, all the parts I've had were very inconsequential.  This is the first part I've had that has more than 3 or 4 lines.  (Note:  My part in the summer production of "Merry Wives of Windsor" was supposed to be larger than it was.  Most of my part got cut due to the surgery.)  Especially when working under the professor we're doing this play for, I've had the most miniscule parts available.  He seems to think that I am good for nothing but elderly, cranky set-dressing.  It has been terribly annoying.  While I don't consider myself to be the greatest actress in the world, I know that I am far more capable than I have been able to show while at the university.  I had wanted to go to ACTF just once.  Sadly, only people with meaty parts ever get nominated.  The chick with 2 lines in one scene is never even noticed by the adjudicators.  That dream is dead, I know.  Our show isn't in the competition.  With this show, I might be able to give a performance that will have some impact.  Unfortunately, this triumph will come only two days before I am to graduate.  Still, I hope that the directors will see it and kick themselves for not giving me a chance sooner (and maybe appologize?).  I know theatre.  I'm good at it.  I'm passionate about it.  I feel at home there.

Tonight at rehearsal, I was given hope.  Because of scheduling conflicts, I had to do the openning scene of the play (usually a two-person affair) reacting to air due to a missing actor.  This is probably the closest I'll ever get to green screen acting.  It was quite fun.  Afterwards, I looked to our director, Vince, for notes on my performance.  Everyone else had left except for me, Vince, and our stage manager.  Vince looked at me and just said, "I have no notes for you.  You make strong choices and I have no problems with them.  You've got it.  Keep doing it."  Ironically, he had performance notes for the missing actor.  *snrk*

As an actor, it is both elation and trepidation you feel when you hear something like that.  Elation is obvious.  Your director enjoyed the performance so much that he can't think of how to change it.  However, there is also trepidation.  You always (if you're any good at acting, that is) feel that there is something you can do better.  You strive for perfection and always feel you fail to acheive it.  A good actor is always re-evaluating their performance. 

I've discovered another strange thing about this show.  This is the first time that I get to properly act opposite Kenneth.  We've been in shows together before, but we've never really had a scene where we interact with each other.  That's probably what I enjoy most about the whole thing.  I get an entire scene at the end where I act primarily off of Kenneth.  Let me tell you, people... It is a joy!  He's so thoughtful as an actor that he makes it easy for you to just lose yourself in the character and the moment.  It is absolutely awe-inspiring to work opposite someone with that level of talent.  I relish every second of it.  I never knew how rewarding it could be to share a stage with someone of that caliber.  I'll always be grateful to him for giving me this chance.

I know many people told me I was crazy to take on this show instead of taking the easy way out and just writing a paper or something for the final project.  You know what, though?  I wouldn't trade this experience for anything.
